content.confidence: 3: You are fairly confident in your assessment. It is possible that you did not understand some parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work. Math/other details were not carefully checked.
content.summary_of_the_paper: Authors propose an algorithm called  D-CIPHER to elicit differential  equations from data.  Authors also propose a new optimization procedure called CoLLie, to help D-CIPHER. Empirical examples are provided.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Strengths:


Authors have a good grasp of some of the challenges of eliciting differential equations from data. They have also planned the scope of the problem carefully, as can be evidenced from the notions like such as evolution form, evolution assumption, derivative-bound part, and derivative-free part, variational-ready PDE. 

Weakness:

The paper is one of bunch of definitions and some empirical analysis. It is not clear that the algorithm D-CIPHER can get past some of the major challenges with eliciting PDEs from data. Essentially, PDE estimation depends on the smooth function used to interpolate between observed data, and hence effectively depends on uncountable imputations between observations. Consequently, the estimated PDE (by any algorithm) tends to be heavily assumption dependent and extremely sensitive to noise. This issue has been deeply studied in the applied math literature and related machine learning literature, but the authors do not seem to be aware of this. The details in the supplementary materials also do not provide any theoretical results or hint that the algorithm indeed provides a consistent estimate of a PDE. I am surprised to find no discussion on or constraints and caveats based on signal to noise ratio, or chaotic systems and other well-known difficult/impossible cases of PDEs.
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib: The paper is clearly written, the quality of the empirical work seems fine but there is a lack of adequate theoretical developments. The algorithm may have some elements of novelty, and the results look reproducible.
content.summary_of_the_review:
This is an empirical study on an algorithm that is claimed to elicit PDEs. However, the lack of a proper theoretical framework and results and a lack of discussion about caveats and limitations make the work weak.


After author comments, several issues are clarified. While some doubts remain, I am changing my scores to better than earlier positions.
content.correctness: 3: Some of the paper’s claims have minor issues. A few statements are not well-supported, or require small changes to be made correct.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 3: The contributions are significant and somewhat new. Aspects of the contributions exist in prior work.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.

content.confidence: 4: You are confident in your assessment, but not absolutely certain. It is unlikely, but not impossible, that you did not understand some parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work.
content.summary_of_the_paper: This paper proposed a PDE/ODE discovery method that includes: (1) a new designed loss function which depends on the variational form of PDE; and (2) an optimization procedure to efficiently solve a constrained least-squares problem. It can discover PDE with nonlinear partial-free part and high-order ODE.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Strength: (1) The designed method has the ability to discover the equation that cannot be represented as a linear combination of derivatives, and the empirical results are promising. (2) Using variational form as the objective in PDE discovery is novel.

Weakness: (1) The relation between the challenges in PDE discovery and the proposed method is not clearly stated. For example, to discover the last four equations in Table 4, why original loss does not work? Is the proposed variational objective function necessary to discover this kind of PDE or just for optimization robustness?  Another example is that it claims the proposed method can find high order differential equations in a robust way. Which techniques can reflect robustness and what makes baseline method unstable? I cannot get why the proposed method has special benefit on learning high-order differential equations neither, because it still depends on the pre-given elements in the dictionary. I feel that there are many claimed points which makes me hard to catch which one is the main point that really works. (2) The presentation is poor. For example, the optimization procedure (CoLLie) is listed as a contribution in the introduction, however, there's no details about the algorithm in section 6. Therefore, I cannot justify whether the proposed procedure is new or not. The figures in experiments are not clearly introduced. For example, what is "Abi. D-CIPHER"? Why does some lines in Figure 2 disappear?
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib:
Clarity: Poor. See the weakness.
Quality: Fair
Novelty: The proposed PDE discovery algorithm is novel, especially the objective function.
Reproducibility: The algorithm can be reproduced since the steps are clear.
content.summary_of_the_review: I have provided detailed evaluation in "Weakness".
content.correctness: 3: Some of the paper’s claims have minor issues. A few statements are not well-supported, or require small changes to be made correct.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 3: The contributions are significant and somewhat new. Aspects of the contributions exist in prior work.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.

content.confidence: 2: You are willing to defend your assessment, but it is quite likely that you did not understand the central parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work. Math/other details were not carefully checked.
content.summary_of_the_paper: The authors propose a symbolic-regression encapsulating approach to discovery of partial differential equations and a heuristic approximate solver of the constrained least-squares problem arising from the definition of learning PDEs as an optimization problem. The approach is evaluated and compared with related approaches on 7 synthetic experiments.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Strengths:
- Well written
- Complete description of the problem and solution
- Comparative and in depth evaluation on multiple problems

Weaknesses:
- High-level abstract description
- Dependence on field estimation and SR algorithm not discussed sufficiently
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib: The work is presented clearly. The approach is novel and the description details allow for reproducibility of the approach. The authors claim that the code for the experimental design will be published upon acceptance.
content.summary_of_the_review: The work addresses an important problem in an area of symbolic regression that requires more attention, as approaches to discovery of PDEs are scarce and mainly developed as extensions to either standard SR methods or methods for learning equations for dynamical systems in the form of ordinary differential equations. I am not an expert in the area of PDEs, but the presented results look convincing. The approach is presented in a manner of framework where different modules can be chosen based on the problem at hand. That being said the effect of the choice of these modules at least in the context of the experimental evaluation in the manuscript deserve a more extensive treatment.
content.correctness: 4: All of the claims and statements are well-supported and correct.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 3: The contributions are significant and somewhat new. Aspects of the contributions exist in prior work.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 3: The contributions are significant and somewhat new. Aspects of the contributions exist in prior work.
